task.title: Creating concept hierarchies
task.shortdesc: Determine which concepts are needed to support your tasks.

taskbody.context: Use the scenarios and tasks identified during development of your task hierarchy to help you identify background concepts that could be needed by users following a task.

step.cmd: Within the map file, create <topicref>s for the concepts implied by the nouns in your task list and in background information in the scenarios.
Eliminate ones that would be familiar to your audience or can be adequately covered in the glossary.
Organize them into higher-level and lower-level concepts.

info.p: This should result in a conceptual hierarchy that the user can review in itself, to make sense of the product's model of the problem domain. Typically you won't want to nest too deeply, since the hierarchy will often be presented in a fairly narrow navigation pane. Also don't create parents with only one child. When necessary, create peer entries with a common qualifying noun, instead of nesting.

step.cmd: Within the conceptual hierarchy, identify which sets of concepts are so closely related they should be read together.
step.info: Set collection-type="family" on a parent concept to make its child concepts link to each other.

step.cmd: Add an href attribute to each <topicref> to point to the equivalent concept topic.
step.info: You can use the map as a to-do list to develop new concepts, and as a way to validate that existing concepts have a place in the conceptual hierarchy of the product and are not misnamed, mistyped, or inappropriate.

taskbody.result: You now have a map that can be used to generate concept navigation for your information set, and add concept-related links among your topics. Parent concepts and child concepts will link to each other, and concepts in a family will link to each other. On output, the links will be sorted by role and type.
